body_html:
Actually I would have like a the following bevavior:
array([1,1,1,1]) where tf.TensorShape denotes an "empty" shape that can be concatenated to a tf.Tensor to receive that Tensor again if shapes match. This would allow me to tf.concat in e.g. a tf.while_loop while having nothing to concatenate with in the first loop iteration.

Is there a reason as to why the shape gets converted to values? It seems pretty inconsistent when the values either denote a shape or values. I cannot find anything in the documentation about it.
body_text:
Actually I would have like a the following bevavior:
array([1,1,1,1]) where tf.TensorShape denotes an "empty" shape that can be concatenated to a tf.Tensor to receive that Tensor again if shapes match. This would allow me to tf.concat in e.g. a tf.while_loop while having nothing to concatenate with in the first loop iteration.
Is there a reason as to why the shape gets converted to values? It seems pretty inconsistent when the values either denote a shape or values. I cannot find anything in the documentation about it.
body:
Actually I would have like a the following bevavior:
`array([1,1,1,1])` where `tf.TensorShape` denotes an "empty" shape that can be concatenated to a `tf.Tensor` to receive that Tensor again if shapes match. This would allow me to `tf.concat` in e.g. a `tf.while_loop` while having nothing to concatenate with in the first loop iteration.

Is there a reason as to why the shape gets converted to values? It seems pretty inconsistent when the values either denote a shape or values. I cannot find anything in the documentation about it.
